reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s percentile-based definition of “best feasible future” (99.99th percentile of a ‘well-informed’ distribution) and argues this makes the 0.5/0.9 thresholds and “mostly-great is rare” claims sensitive to modeling choices, especially under heavy tails. This is moderately central: the essay uses this benchmark to normalize/define ‘mostly-great’ and to motivate comparisons, but much of the “no easy eutopia” case also rests on independent considerations (fragility/multiplicative factors, moral-view fussiness) that could be reformulated without that particular percentile convention. The critique has moderate strength: it plausibly shows epistemic instability and a potential definitional artifact/circularity pressure, but it doesn’t directly refute the underlying claim that good futures may be a narrow target under many moral views; it mainly challenges how the target is operationalized and how robust the rarity conclusion is to changes in the reference distribution. Most claims are correct/plausible (heavy-tail sensitivity, dependence on hypothesis class), with slight overstatement in implying strong circularity rather than a conventional normalization choice. It’s clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: "Percentile thresholds can shift with model scope"
